Award.AwardTitle: Manufacturing of Self-Powered Nanosensor Systems by Pulsed Laser Processing

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Economically viable self-powered micro and nano devices promise to revolutionize technologies in healthcare, environmental, consumer and military applications. Piezoelectric nanowires can convert mechanical energy into electrical power, and extend the applications for implanted biomedical devices. They can be used where solar energy is unreliable. However, there are significant roadblocks for nano and micro systems to realize their full potential. Current methods used for making these systems require many discrete processes, expensive equipment in addition to a clean room environment resulting in prohibitive cost. Each process requires long preparation, handling and processing times. For faster throughput, huge investments must be made for automation, justifiable only for mass production. In general, cost has become a roadblock against capturing the benefits of most nanotechnology innovations. Therefore, a need in nanomanufacturing is to develop innovative flexible processes that enable integration for efficient small and medium lot size production. This award is to work on a single equipment that can perform multiple tasks required for processing heterogeneous nanomaterials and integrating them into a device. The non-cleanroom method is scalable and has shown more than two-orders-of-magnitude improvement in zinc oxide nanowire performance, reduction of six processes in to one, and reduction of equipment investment by a factor of ten. This research advances the fundamental understanding of the capabilities and performance of this single-step approach for processing and integrating heterogeneous materials and devices. The project plans to recruit female and under-represented minority graduate students, use the research results in new coursework and organize symposia as a platform for stimulating and exchanging new ideas.

The overarching goal of this project is to study and develop a novel integrated nanomanufacturing process for self-powered nanosensor systems. The research involves understanding the process-structure-properties-performance relationships in these materials and systems. The objectives of this research project are to uncover the correlations among the nucleation density, growth and morphology of the ZnO nanowire arrays produced by a pulsed laser; the correlation of the piezoelectric properties and the morphology of the ZnO nanowire arrays; the correlation of the performance of the piezoelectric nanogenerator subassembly and the piezoelectric properties, and the integration of a nanosensor into the self-powered nanogenerator system. The main outcome of this research is the understanding of the mechanisms and relationships among pulsed laser parameters, crystal nucleation and morphology control of ZnO nanowire arrays, and its impact on the material properties and performance in self-powered nanosensing systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Pulsed lasers are studied as new tools to realize competitive nanomanufacturing. The capabilities of pulsed lasers as promising tools for research, design, manufacturing, and control rely on the flexibility due to the great variety of operation parameters, and the inherent precision in aspects of time, spatial resolution, and energy input. As new tools, the project studied for (1) fundamental understanding and technological capabilities of pulsed laser-induced chemical synthesis and (2) the application of Pulsed Laser in nanomanufacturing of self-powered Nanosensor Systems. The outcomes are summarized in the following: 

(1)   Fundamental understanding and technological capabilities of pulsed laser-induced chemical synthesis (C. Richard Liu, PI): In order to study the capabilities of pulsed laser in controlled synthesis, a thermal model was developed to predict the local temperature change due to the very short period of irradiation by a nano-second pulsed laser. Combining with the classical Gibbs free energy theories, a set of guidelines were developed for precision control for pulsed laser-induced chemical synthesis. Zinc oxide crystals were studied as an example case, showing the relationship between the wide range variables of pulsed laser including repetition rate, energy area density, power density, irradiation duration, etc. and the material structures of deposited crystals in aspects of crystal density, size, shape, crystalline properties, surface morphologies, growth rate, etc. Mechanisms from thermodynamic and kinetic aspects were explored. Pulsed laser-induced different heating conditions were found to separate two crystallization processes with different energy barriers, one dominated by a burst of nucleation and the other dominated by crystal growth through particle aggregation. For the study of the fundamental mechanisms in crystallization, pulsed laser initiated and controlled the crystallization in its early stage, and the crystal evolution were observed and analyzed by in-situ observation in transmission electron microscopy (TEM). Crystal growth from intermediate monomers was studied first time by an electron beam under the condition without a precursor solution environment, providing crucial process information of crystal evolution. The observation indicated multistage processes by continuous mass and phase transfer among intermediate monomers, including some new dynamics not discovered before. The result has contributed toward a unified theory of crystallization, classic AND non-classic. This research shows the capabilities of pulsed laser in realizing precision control for the targeted synthesis in nanomanufacturing, providing unique insight to crystallization mechanisms, and extending prospects to scientific research of other energy beam induced processes.

(2)   Application of pulsed laser in manufacturing of self-powered nanosensor systems (Wenzhou Wu, co-PI): To identify the feasibility of the pulsed laser in manufacturing of self-powered nanosensor systems, the pulsed-laser synthesized ZnO nanowires were integrated into a piezoelectric nanogenerator assembly that converts the mechanical stimuli into electric power. The electrical outputs of the as-integrated ZnO piezoelectric nanogenerators were systematically characterized. The correlation between the laser processing and the energy conversion performance (output voltage/current, power, and output power density) of piezoelectric nanogenerator assembly was identified and examined through electromechanically coupled characterizations and theoretical studies. A physics-based, data-driven scheme was developed for the first time to learn and map the correlation between the performance of the ZnO nanogenerator and the manufacturing parameters through formal statistical analysis. A behavioral model was developed to reveal the apparent effects of growth parameters and identify the related process-structure-property-performance relation. The piezoelectric outputs from the ZnO nanowire nanogenerators were examined as a function of the morphology parameters, namely the length, diameter, and density, of the ZnO nanowires. These fundamental morphology parameters are closely related to the laser processing parameters and the laser-engineered nucleation/growth processes, as identified in the outcome (1). The gained fundamental knowledge in the correlation between the laser processing parameters and the energy conversion performance of nanogenerator assembly, at the hierarchical levels of material, structure, and device, enables the manufacturing of ZnO nanowires nanogenerator with high quality and reliable performance. With these understandings and technological capabilities, the team further explored and demonstrated the feasibility of heterogeneously integrating the subassemblies of nanogenerator and nanosensors into a self-powered nanosensor system through laser-induced integration. ZnO nanowires array with optimized morphologies, as suggested by the established model, were manufactured and successfully integrated with a nanowire-based photosensor to demonstrate for the first time a pulsed-laser integrated self-powered nanosensor system. Such a self-powered nanosensor system exhibits good photodetection performance using the piezoelectric outputs generated by the ZnO nanowires nanogenerator as the operation power, without using an external power supply. The result has contributed toward a hierarchical framework for analyzing and learning the fundamental process-structure-property relation in the pulsed laser manufacturing of the ZnO nanowires nanogenerator and sensor system, as well as guiding the process design and optimization for producing functional assemblies with targeted performance. This research provides unique insight to holistic design of process, material and device at hierarchical levels, and ushering in new opportunities for utilizing energy beam processes in manufacturing and integrating versatile nanomaterials into nanosystems with diversified functionalities.

 


Last Modified: 07/16/2020
Modified by: C. Richard Liu
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Pulsed lasers are studied as new tools to realize competitive nanomanufacturing. The capabilities of pulsed lasers as promising tools for research, design, manufacturing, and control rely on the flexibility due to the great variety of operation parameters, and the inherent precision in aspects of time, spatial resolution, and energy input. As new tools, the project studied for (1) fundamental understanding and technological capabilities of pulsed laser-induced chemical synthesis and (2) the application of Pulsed Laser in nanomanufacturing of self-powered Nanosensor Systems. The outcomes are summarized in the following: (1) Fundamental understanding and technological capabilities of pulsed laser-induced chemical synthesis (C. Richard Liu, PI): In order to study the capabilities of pulsed laser in controlled synthesis, a thermal model was developed to predict the local temperature change due to the very short period of irradiation by a nano-second pulsed laser. Combining with the classical Gibbs free energy theories, a set of guidelines were developed for precision control for pulsed laser-induced chemical synthesis. Zinc oxide crystals were studied as an example case, showing the relationship between the wide range variables of pulsed laser including repetition rate, energy area density, power density, irradiation duration, etc. and the material structures of deposited crystals in aspects of crystal density, size, shape, crystalline properties, surface morphologies, growth rate, etc. Mechanisms from thermodynamic and kinetic aspects were explored. Pulsed laser-induced different heating conditions were found to separate two crystallization processes with different energy barriers, one dominated by a burst of nucleation and the other dominated by crystal growth through particle aggregation. The result has contributed toward a unified theory of crystallization, classic AND non-classic. This research shows the capabilities of pulsed laser in realizing precision control for the targeted synthesis in nanomanufacturing, providing unique insight to crystallization mechanisms, and extending prospects to scientific research of other energy beam induced processes. (2) Application of pulsed laser in manufacturing of self-powered nanosensor systems (Wenzhou Wu, co-PI): To identify the feasibility of the pulsed laser in manufacturing of self-powered nanosensor systems, the pulsed-laser synthesized ZnO nanowires were integrated into a piezoelectric nanogenerator assembly that converts the mechanical stimuli into electric power. A physics-based, data-driven scheme was developed for the first time to learn and map the correlation between the performance of the ZnO nanogenerator and the manufacturing parameters through formal statistical analysis. A behavioral model was developed to reveal the apparent effects of growth parameters and identify the related process-structure-property-performance relation. The piezoelectric outputs from the ZnO nanowire nanogenerators were examined as a function of the morphology parameters, namely the length, diameter, and density, of the ZnO nanowires. These fundamental morphology parameters are closely related to the laser processing parameters and the laser-engineered nucleation/growth processes, as identified in the outcome (1). The gained fundamental knowledge in the correlation between the laser processing parameters and the energy conversion performance of nanogenerator assembly, at the hierarchical levels of material, structure, and device, enables the manufacturing of ZnO nanowires nanogenerator with high quality and reliable performance. With these understandings and technological capabilities, the team further explored and demonstrated the feasibility of heterogeneously integrating the subassemblies of nanogenerator and nanosensors into a self-powered nanosensor system through laser-induced integration. ZnO nanowires array with optimized morphologies, as suggested by the established model, were manufactured and successfully integrated with a nanowire-based photosensor to demonstrate for the first time a pulsed-laser integrated self-powered nanosensor system. Such a self-powered nanosensor system exhibits good photodetection performance using the piezoelectric outputs generated by the ZnO nanowires nanogenerator as the operation power, without using an external power supply. The result has contributed toward a hierarchical framework for analyzing and learning the fundamental process-structure-property relation in the pulsed laser manufacturing of the ZnO nanowires nanogenerator and sensor system, as well as guiding the process design and optimization for producing functional assemblies with targeted performance. This research provides unique insight to holistic design of process, material and device at hierarchical levels, and ushering in new opportunities for utilizing energy beam processes in manufacturing and integrating versatile nanomaterials into nanosystems with diversified functionalities.
